#Text=James Stewart , Earl of Arran
#Text=Arms of James Stewart
#Text=Captain James Stewart , Earl of Arran ( died 1595 ) was created Earl of Arran by the young King James VI , who wrested the title from James Hamilton , 3rd Earl of Arran .
#Text=He rose to become Lord Chancellor of Scotland and was eventually murdered in 1595 .
#Text=Career
#Text=He was the second son of Andrew Stewart , 2nd Lord Ochiltree , by his wife Agnes , the daughter of John Cunningham , 5th of Capringtoun , Ayrshire .
#Text=Stewart 's sister , Margaret , was married to the reformer John Knox .

#Text=In April 1573 , James was sent as a " pledge " or hostage to England for the security of the English army and artillery sent to the " Lang Siege " of Edinburgh Castle , which was held by supporters of Mary Queen of Scots .
#Text=Regent Morton
#Text=gave him £55 for his expenses in England . [ 1 ]
#Text=He was Captain of the Royal Guard of James VI , served with the Dutch forces in the Netherlands against the Spanish , and returned to Scotland in 1579 . [ 2 ]
#Text=James quickly became a favourite of the young king , and in 1580 was made Gentleman of the Bedchamber .

#Text=He was a follower of Esmé Stewart , and in January 1580 he accused the former Regent Morton , still the effective power in Scotland , of participation in the murder of Henry Stuart , Lord Darnley .
#Text=Stewart was rewarded as Tutor of Arran , with powers over the earldom of the mentally-ill James Hamilton , 3rd Earl of Arran , then made Earl of Arran on 22 April 1581 .
#Text=He also claimed the position of second person in the land through being nearest to the king by descent , other than the now-insane third earl . [ 2 ]
#Text=In July he married Elizabeth Stewart , the divorced former wife of the King 's great-uncle , Robert Stewart , once Earl of Lennox and now Earl of March .
#Text=Elizabeth , the Countess of Arran , born 1549 , was the daughter of John Stewart , 4th Earl of Atholl .
#Text=The Lennox-Arran administration
#Text=Esmé Stewart was made Earl , then Duke , of Lennox , and he and Arran became partners in government , and rivals for the supremacy . [ 2 ]

#Text=Their government of Scotland , and their correspondence with France and Spain , made them unpopular in England and with the " ultra-Protestant " sector at home , although the young King greatly admired Lennox and enjoyed his company .
#Text=The Ruthven raid
#Text=In August 1582 Lennox and Arran held the Privy Council at Perth , and then returned to Dalkeith Palace near Edinburgh .

#Text=James VI was invited to stay hunting in Perthshire , and he was taken at Huntingtower Castle by the Earl of Gowrie and his political faction on 22 August 1582 , a kidnap known as the Ruthven Raid .
#Text=The next day they gave the King their supplication or mandate , which stated ;

#Text=We have suffered now about the space of two years such false accusations , calumnies , oppressions and persecutions , by the means of the Duke of Lennox and him who is called the Earl of Arran , that the like of their insolencies and enormities were never heretofore born with in Scotland .
#Text=Arran went to Huntingtower and was arrested by the raiders .
#Text=Lennox was sent in exile to France and died .

#Text=Gowrie ran Scotland for ten months , after issuing an indictment against Lennox and Arran that included the detail that the Countess of Arran was " a vile and impudent woman , over famous for her monstrous doings , not without suspicion of the devilish magical art .

#Text= Arran was permitted to attend some council meetings to bolster support for the new regime . [ 3 ]

column1: #Text=The Arran supremacy

#Text=Arran assembled a force of 12,000 men and regained power in July 1583 , [ 2 ] an ascendancy that would last for two years , and the Ruthven Raiders and their followers were banished to Newcastle upon Tyne .
#Text=Gowrie was executed .
#Text=After May 1584 , Arran was always recorded first in the lists of those attending the Scottish Privy Council .
#Text=He became governor of Edinburgh Castle , provost of the city , and lieutenant-general of the royal army .
#Text=He acted against the Presbyterian wing of the Scottish church , and the banished lords of the Ruthven Raid , who had returned to assault Stirling Castle .
#Text=The role of his wife in the administration also attracted the censure of Edinburgh Kirk ministers .
#Text=Arran 's rule was undermined in part by the machinations of his own diplomat in London , the young Master of Gray .
#Text=By February 1585 , Elizabeth opened two lines of communication in Scotland , one with Arran and another with the Master . [ 5 ]
#Text=Arran fell from power after a border incident when the Englishman Francis Russell , son of the second Earl of Bedford , was killed with a " shot from a dag " on 27 July 1585 .
#Text=Arran was accused of involvement by the English ambassador , Nicholas Wotton and James VI on first hearing the news had offered to send Arran as a prisoner to England . [ 6 ]
#Text=Instead Arran was imprisoned at St Andrews Castle and then placed in house arrest at his own Kinneil House .

#Text=One account says he went from Kinneil to Ayr and embarked on a boat with the royal jewels including the Great H of Scotland or ' Kingis Eitche ' , but was forced to give the jewels to George Home . [ 7 ]
#Text=He was unable to prevent the Banished Lords of the Ruthven Raid returning from England , seizing Stirling Castle on 4 November 1586 , and declaring him a traitor . [ 2 ]
#Text=Retirement and death
#Text=Avoiding plans for his banishment , and despite being ordered to leave the country , he spent the rest of his life in retirement in Ayrshire . [ 8 ]

#Text=He did however remain in communication with James , and may have carried out some secret missions for him . [ 2 ] In December 1592 Stewart came to Holyroodhouse and met the king by the kennels .
#Text=He then entered the presence chamber where some called him ' Lord Chancellor ' and then met Anne of Denmark and kissed her hand .
#Text=However , James let it be proclaimed in churches that he would not employ Stewart again . [ 9 ]
#Text=He was murdered by Sir James Douglas of Parkhead , nephew of Regent Morton , on 5 December 1595 . [ 10 ]
